0: A CBS News investigation into a charity for wounded veterans, the Wounded Warrior Project, looks into how the charity spends its donation money. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR What caught our attention is how the Wounded Warrior Project spends donations compared to other long-respected charities. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR For example, Disabled American Veterans Charitable Service Trust spends 96 percent of its budget on vets. Fisher House devotes 91 percent. But according to public records reported by "Charity Navigator," the Wounded Warrior Project spends 60 percent on vets. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Where is the money is going? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In its commercials, Wounded Warrior Project appeals to the American public's generosity, and it works. In 2014 alone the group received more than $300 million in donations. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Army Staff Sergeant Erick Millette CBS News NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Their mission is to honor and empower wounded warriors, but what the public doesn't see is how they spend their money," said Army Staff Sergeant Erick Millette. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Millette came home from Iraq in 2006 with a bronze star and a purple heart -- along with a traumatic brain injury and PTSD. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Initially, he admired the charity's work, and participated in its programs. He took a job as a public speaker with Wounded Warrior Project in 2013. But after two years, he quit. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "You're using our injuries, our darkest days, our hardships, to make money. So you can have these big parties," he told CBS News. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Millette said he witnessed lavish spending on staff. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Let's get a Mexican mariachi band in there, let's get maracas made with [the] WWP logo, put them on every staff member's desk. Let's get it catered and have a big old party," he described. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Going to a nice fancy restaurant is not team building. Staying at a lavish hotel at the beach here in Jacksonville, and requiring staff that lives in the area to stay at the hotel is not team building," Millette continued. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR CBS News spoke to more than 40 former employees who described a charity where spending was out of control. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Two of those former employees were so fearful of retaliation they asked that their faces not to be shown on camera. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It was extremely extravagant. Dinners and alcohol, and just total accessm" one employee explained. He continued, saying that for a charitable organization that's serving veterans, the spending on resorts and alcohol is "what the military calls fraud waste and abuse." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Wounded Warrior Project CEO Steven Nardizzi NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR According to the charity's tax forms, spending on conferences and meetings went from $1.7 million in 2010, to $26 million in 2014. That's about the same amount the group spends on combat stress recovery -- its top program. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Former employees say spending has skyrocketed since Steven Nardizzi took over as CEO in 2009. Many point to the 2014 annual meeting at a luxury resort in Colorado Springs as typical of his style. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "He rappelled down the side of a building at one of the all hands events. He's come in on a Segway, he's come in on a horse." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR About 500 staff members attended the four-day conference in Colorado. The price tag? About $3 million. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Donors don't want you to have a $2,500 bar tab. Donors don't want you to fly every staff member once a year to some five-star resort and whoop it up and call it team building," said Millette. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Colorado Springs resort where a 2014 WWP conference was held NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Wounded Warrior Project declined CBS News' repeated interview requests for Nardizzi, but offered their Director of Alumni and a recipient of their services, Captain Ryan Kules. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kules denied there was excessive spending on conferences. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's the best use of donor dollars to ensure we are providing programs and services to our warriors and families at the highest quality." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR When asked why conferences were held at five-star resorts instead of cheaper options, Kules provided the same answer. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Capt. Ryan Kules, WWP Director of Alumni CBS News NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Like I said, it's to make sure we are aligned and can build as a team. Be able to be able to provide the best quality services." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "WWP and those donor dollars trained me to speak and be a voice, and that's exactly what I'm doing," said Millette. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I'm sorry, but I'll be damned if you're gonna take hard-working Americans' money and drink it and waste it." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kules also told CBS News the charity did not spend $3 million on the Colorado conference, but he was not there and was unable to say what it did cost.
